page.title: 13CHANGING TIMES 1
page.content: "I came to Borehamwood fom London in 1953. Theobald Street was a country road which seemed to go on for ever. There were big houses on both sides, which have now been replaced by modern buildings. Ours was one of the first roads on the Council estate to be occupied. There were no pavements or road-surfacing, just a muddy track. Halfway down scaffolding had been erected to prevent cars passing through to the rest of the estate which was still under construction. There were a few shops next to the Wellington pub, including a bakers and a butchers, with cattle grazing in the field next to it. In the main road was a small Sainsbury's and Boots the chemist. There were also rows of cottages along each side of the shops: in one of these the local doctor held his surgery."
